Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old individual with poorly-controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM1) and complications such as retinopathy, neuropathy, nephropathy, and hypertension. The patient was admitted with complaints of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and dry cough. The patient was found to be in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and acute-on-chronic renal failure, likely due to left-sided community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) or aspiration pneumonia/pneumonitis.

The patient received a large dose of exogenous insulin overnight, leading to hypoglycemia. To address this, the patient was started on a continuous D51/2NS infusion with 4 boluses of D50. The patient has been on regular insulin at a rate of 1 unit per hour. Other medications include pantoprazole (Protonix), lorazepam (Ativan), and heparin sodium (prophylaxis).

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate of 88 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 133/81 mmHg to 158/96 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on nasal cannula. The patient is receiving respiratory support with supplemental oxygen.

The patient's lab results show a hemoglobin level of 8.3 g/dL, leukocyte count of 232 K/uL, blood glucose level of 197 mg/dL, bicarbonate level of 7.1 mg/dL, sodium level of 107 mEq/L, potassium level of 4.6 mEq/L, chloride level of 25.0%, and creatinine level of 7.3 mg/dL. The patient also has a WBC count of 12.3, Hct of 25.0, platelet count of 232, and BUN of 32 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal range.

The patient is being treated with ceftriaxone and levofloxacin for 7 days, which can be tapered to levofloxacin for an additional 5 days (renally dosed). Sputum cultures, urine strep Ag, and urine legionella Ag will be followed up.

The patient's assessment includes pneumonia, DKA, abdominal pain/nausea, renal failure, anemia, and ICU care. The patient is on full code status, with access through a femoral triple-lumen catheter. Prophylactic medications include heparin for DVT and stress ulcer prevention. The patient's disposition is to be monitored on the ICU today.
